newsitem.title: FRANCE: FRENCH SOCCER STAR IN COURT FOR INDECENT EXPOSURE.
newsitem.headline: FRENCH SOCCER STAR IN COURT FOR INDECENT EXPOSURE.

text.p: A state prosecutor on Wednesday asked a court to give French soccer international Patrice Loko a suspended eight-month sentence on charges of indecent exposure and damaging property.

The 27-year-old Paris-Saint-Germain forward ran amok two years ago, kicking cars outside a Paris nightclub, insulting and spitting at police who arrested him and repeatedly exposing his genitals to a policewoman.
An embarrassed Loko told the Paris court he did not remember anything from what French media called his "crazy night".
"I still cannot understand how this happened. I want to apologise," he said.
Loko's lawyer said a prison term, even suspended, could lead to the revocation of his player's licence.
Policemen testified that Loko had boasted that high-placed friends would rapidly get him out of the police station, compared his huge income to their salaries and poured abuse on them.
"In 18 years as a policeman, I had never been so insulted. I could not sleep for two days," one policeman said.
PSG Chairman Jean-Francois Domergue, testifying in his players's favour, said Loko, who won his 26th international cap for France against England on June 7, had since changed his ways.
The prosecutor asked the court to order Loko to compensate victims and submit to regular medical and psychiatric tests.
"A star athlete should serve as a model for young people," prosecutor Odile Faivre said. But she admitted that the death of Loko's young son in December 1992 could explain his behaviour.
Tests conducted by police showed Loko had not consumed any alcohol or taken any drugs on the night of his rampage. The results of psychiatric examinations were also normal.
The court will give its verdict on June 25.
